title: Diwali: The Night a Billion Lamps Said Welcome Home
excerpt: Every year, on the darkest night of the darkest fortnight of the Hindu calendar, India lights up as if the stars decided to descend. Diwali is not one story â€” it is several stories, all arriving at the same truth: light wins. And it always comes home.

body.heading: The Night Ram Returned
body.text: The most widely told origin of Diwali is also the most tender one. After fourteen years of exile in the forest â€” fourteen years of war, loss, and impossible trials â€” Ram, Sita, and Lakshmana finally returned to Ayodhya. The city had waited. Not passively, not reluctantly â€” it had waited with the particular anguish of a home that knows its beloved is coming back but cannot reach out to bring them faster. When the people of Ayodhya learned that Ram was finally near, they did not simply stand at the gates and cheer. They lit diyas â€” thousands of tiny clay lamps â€” along every street, every rooftop, every windowsill. Not because anyone told them to. But because when something beloved returns from darkness, the only adequate response is to fill every corner of darkness with light. That is Diwali. Not a celebration invented by a king, but a welcome invented by a city that missed its prince.

body.heading: The Night Lakshmi Walks
body.text: Diwali falls on Amavasya â€” the new moon night, when the sky is at its darkest. In the Hindu tradition, this is not a coincidence. Goddess Lakshmi, the deity of wealth, prosperity, and abundance, is said to leave her celestial home on this night and walk among the earth, entering the homes that are clean, bright, and welcoming. The diyas are not just decoration â€” they are a beacon. "We are ready for you. We have swept the floors. We have made rangoli at the threshold. The lamp is burning." Lakshmi Puja is performed on Diwali evening with meticulous care: the household idol is bathed and adorned, coins and account books are offered for blessing (a tradition especially observed by merchants and traders), and the goddess is invited to enter and stay. The belief is not transactional â€” it is relational. Lakshmi does not come to those who want wealth. She comes to those who have made their homes worthy of her presence.

body.heading: Five Days, Five Stories
body.text: What many people do not realize is that Diwali is not a single day â€” it is a five-day festival, each day carrying its own name and significance. Dhanteras (Day 1) celebrates Dhanvantari, the divine physician who emerged from the cosmic ocean bearing the nectar of immortality; it is auspicious for buying gold or new utensils. Naraka Chaturdasi (Day 2, also called Choti Diwali) marks Lord Krishna's victory over the demon Narakasura, and people wake before dawn to bathe in sesame oil â€” symbolically washing off darkness. Lakshmi Puja (Day 3) is the main Diwali night: the burst of light and prayer. Govardhan Puja (Day 4) honors the day Krishna lifted the Govardhan mountain on his little finger to shelter his village from Indra's wrath. And Bhai Dooj (Day 5) celebrates the bond between siblings, with sisters praying for their brothers' long life. Five days, five myths, one unified impulse: honor what is sacred before it slips away.

body.heading: Why We Light Diyas, Not Switches
body.text: In an age of electricity, it would be easy â€” perhaps even logical â€” to simply turn on the lights. But there is something that a diya does that a light bulb cannot. A clay lamp is made of the earth, fueled by oil or ghee, lit by a human hand, and sustained by a tiny flame that flickers and breathes. It is alive. Every diya lit is an act of human agency against darkness â€” not a passive switch, but a deliberate, effortful kindling. The Upanishads speak of the Atman, the individual soul, as a flame of the Supreme â€” the same light, in a smaller form. When we light a diya on Diwali, we are not merely decorating. We are, in some ancient and wordless way, affirming that the light in us is real, that it is connected to the larger light, and that no amount of darkness â€” personal or collective â€” can extinguish it. That is why, even when we could press a switch, we still cup our hands around a tiny flame and carry it carefully across the room.

body.heading: Celebrating Diwali With Intention
body.text: The most meaningful Diwali begins before the festival itself â€” with cleaning. The tradition of cleaning the home before Diwali is not about impressing guests. It is about making space. Physically and spiritually, clearing the accumulated clutter of the year prepares the home (and the mind) for what is to be invited in. On the day of Lakshmi Puja, light the first diya with a prayer rather than routine: ask for the specific kind of abundance you seek â€” not just money, but clarity, health, loving relationships, creative energy. Use natural, handmade diyas where possible; the act of arranging them by hand, one by one, is itself a meditation. Share sweets with neighbors, including those you may have had tension with â€” Diwali is explicitly a time for renewing bonds. And on that darkest new-moon night, when you stand among a thousand lamps and the whole street smells of marigolds and smoke and ghee, let yourself feel it: this is what it looks like when human beings refuse to accept the dark.
